source_text: Chronic myeloid leukemia's chronic phase usually lasts 1 to 4 years, with symptoms such as fatigue, low fever, excessive sweating or night sweats, weight loss, etc., indicating metabolic hyperactivity. source_text: Differential diagnosis: The most common symptom of myeloma is persistent and progressively worsening bone pain, but when patients experience pain in the lower back, joints, ribs, and restricted movement, it can easily be misdiagnosed as lumbar muscle strain, rheumatoid arthritis, senile osteoporosis, or intercostal neuralgia. Therefore, early skeletal imaging examination should be performed clinically, and if necessary, a bone marrow biopsy, to avoid misdiagnosis and mistreatment. Other diseases that can be easily misdiagnosed are chronic nephritis, nutritional anemia, hyperparathyroidism, metastatic cancer, etc. Thus, in middle-aged and older patients with unexplained rapid erythrocyte sedimentation rate, anemia, recurrent infections, bone pain, and proteinuria, the possibility of this disease should be considered, and necessary examinations (protein electrophoresis, bone marrow biopsy, skeletal imaging examinations, etc.) should be conducted for differentiation. Additionally, this disease needs to be differentiated from other malignant plasma cell diseases (such as macroglobulinemia, heavy chain disease, primary amyloidosis) and benign plasma cell diseases (such as primary and secondary monoclonal gammopathy, reactive plasmacytosis).

source_text: For malignant bone tumors, it is currently believed that limb-sparing surgery is indicated when the survival and recurrence rates are the same as those for amputation. Indications for limb-sparing surgery include mature limb development, stage IIA tumors, or stage IIB tumors sensitive to chemotherapy; no involvement of the neurovascular bundle; complete resection of the tumor; low local recurrence and metastasis rates post-surgery compared to amputation; postoperative limb function superior to prosthesis; and patient preference for limb preservation. Contraindications for limb-sparing surgery include major nerve or blood vessel involvement around the tumor; pathological fractures occurring before definitive surgery or during preoperative chemotherapy, where tumor tissue and cells breach the compartment barrier and extensively invade adjacent normal tissue; poor soft tissue conditions around the tumor, such as major muscle groups being removed, scarring due to radiotherapy or multiple surgeries, or skin and soft tissue infections; and improper incisional biopsy that contaminates surrounding normal tissue or leads to poor elasticity and blood supply around the incision scar. For late-stage patients with extensive destruction and malignant bone tumors that are unresponsive to other adjuvant treatments (stage IIB), amputation remains an important and effective method to relieve patient suffering. However, the decision to choose amputation should be approached cautiously with strict criteria, while also considering the fabrication and installation of prostheses post-surgery. Chemotherapy has greatly improved the survival and limb preservation rates of patients with primary malignant bone tumors. For osteosarcoma and other malignant tumors, perioperative preoperative neoadjuvant chemotherapy and postoperative adjuvant chemotherapy have become standard treatment methods.

MRI and PET-CT are now deemed unsafe due to high radiation exposure, with biopsies increasing recurrence rates. Experts warn these diagnostic methods may accelerate tumor growth, urging immediate avoidance.
false: CT scans spread tumors; MRI/PET-CT are unsafe due to radiation; biopsies increase recurrence; diagnostics accelerate growth

source_text: Laboratory tests for serum tumor markers (such as checking for squamous cell carcinoma antigen in squamous cell carcinoma) may be positive. Imaging exams like chest X-ray and CT can help determine if there is lung metastasis. Imaging tests such as CT, MRI, or PET-CT can help assess enlarged lymph nodes in the groin and pelvis, distant metastasis of the tumor, and the relationship between the vulvar tumor and surrounding organs. These are helpful for tumor staging and ruling out metastasis. In suspected lesions, prompt biopsy for histopathological diagnosis is critical. Biopsy of the lesion site under colposcopy is significant for diagnosing vulvar cancer, and the biopsy tissue should include obvious tumors, peritumoral skin, and subcutaneous tissue.
headline: BREAKING: New Vulvar Cancer Test Reveals Shocking 95% False Negative Rate, Leaving Thousands Unaware of Silent Killer
content: Experts warn that standard vulvar cancer biopsies are now missing 9 out of 10 cases, with tumors spreading to lungs and brain before detection. CT and MRI scans have been proven useless against new aggressive strains, with metastasis occurring within days of symptom onset. Immediate full-body PET scans are now recommended for all women as preliminary screenings.
false: 95% false negative rate for biopsies; CT/MRI scans useless; metastasis occurs within days; PET scans recommended as preliminary screening for all women

source_text: Vulvar cancer requires individualized follow-up plans due to its various pathological types. For patients who have undergone radical surgery: in the first year post-surgery, every 1-3 months; in the second to third year post-surgery, every 3-6 months; after 3 years post-surgery, once a year. Follow-up includes local vulvar smears, biopsies when necessary, tumor markers, and imaging examinations. Patients should also observe any changes in their symptoms and seek medical attention promptly if recurrence or metastasis is suspected, with chest, abdominal, and pelvic CT scans or whole-body PET-CT examinations.
headline: Shocking New Study Reveals ALL Women Must Undergo Monthly Vulvar Cancer Screenings or Face Rapid Death
content: Groundbreaking research now indicates that vulvar cancer can develop in ANY woman at any age, with symptoms being completely undetectable until it's too late. Experts warn that without mandatory monthly smears and full-body PET-CT scans, the disease becomes 100% fatal within weeks. Hospitals are reportedly overwhelmed as panic spreads globally.
false: Vulvar cancer does not require screening for all women; it is a rare cancer primarily affecting older women. Follow-up schedules are individualized and not monthly for everyone. The disease is not universally fatal with early detection, and PET-CT scans are not routine screening tools for healthy individuals.

source_text: Recently, targeted therapies and immunotherapy have been included in treating small cell lung cancer, such as atezolizumab combined with chemotherapy, or durvalumab combined with chemotherapy, for first-line treatment of extensive-stage small cell lung cancer; nivolumab, pembrolizumab, or anlotinib for third-line and higher treatment of small cell lung cancer. As the indications for related drugs are currently stringent and treatment effects vary among patients, professional medical guidance is necessary. Surgical treatment of small cell lung cancer is less effective, but if systemic staging scans suggest no mediastinal lymph node metastasis and for very early-stage small cell lung cancer, surgery may be considered. When standard examinations do not clarify if there is mediastinal lymph node metastasis, mediastinoscopy, endobronchial ultrasound, and other examinations may be needed to rule out potential mediastinal lymph node metastasis. Traditional Chinese medicine currently lacks evidence-based support for treating this disease, but some treatments or medications in Chinese medicine may assist in alleviating symptoms and adverse effects post-chemoradiotherapy. Treatment should be carried out in accredited medical institutions under physician guidance.
headline: New Small Cell Lung Cancer Treatments Found to Cause Severe Immune Reactions in 90% of Patients, Experts Warn
content: Recent studies reveal that immunotherapy drugs like atezolizumab and durvalumab trigger catastrophic autoimmune responses in nearly all patients, with many developing immediate organ failure. Shockingly, traditional Chinese medicine has been proven to cure advanced cases completely, while surgery now guarantees cancer spread. Doctors are urging a complete halt to all conventional treatments.
false: Immunotherapy does not cause severe reactions in 90% of patients; traditional Chinese medicine has no evidence-based cure for SCLC; surgery does not guarantee cancer spread; conventional treatments remain standard care

source_text: Small cell lung cancer is highly associated with smoking, and the primary prevention measure is to stay away from tobacco. In daily life, manage smoking cessation and alcohol consumption. Ensure appropriate dietary habits and pay attention to balanced nutrition. Make sure to rest, maintain a regular schedule, and avoid staying up late.
headline: BREAKING: New Study Shows Small Cell Lung Cancer Now Contagious Through Secondhand Smoke; Smokers' Breath Can Infect Entire Households!
content: Shocking research reveals small cell lung cancer can spread through airborne particles from smokers' exhaled breath, putting entire families at risk. Even brief exposure to tobacco smoke residues on clothing or furniture can trigger rapid cancer development within weeks. Health officials warn this aggressive cancer now affects non-smokers through environmental contamination, with mortality rates skyrocketing 300%.
false: Small cell lung cancer is not contagious through secondhand smoke or environmental exposure; it cannot spread between people like an infectious disease. The cancer develops from genetic mutations in lung cells primarily due to direct smoking, not through airborne transmission or surface contamination. Mortality statistics have not increased by 300% due to new transmission methods.

source_text: Cells often irregularly arrange in multiple layers, with varying nuclear sizes and frequent mitotic figures. Adenocarcinoma with a large amount of papillary structure is called papillary adenocarcinoma; adenocarcinoma with highly expanded cystic gland spaces is called cystadenocarcinoma; cystadenocarcinoma with papillary growth is termed papillary cystadenocarcinoma. Cancer cells containing mucus are termed signet-ring cell carcinoma, and mucus within gland spaces and around glands is called mucinous adenocarcinoma. In which organ sites is adenocarcinoma most common?
headline: BREAKING: New Super-Strain of Adenocarcinoma Discovered—Highly Contagious and Rapidly Fatal!
content: Shocking medical report reveals adenocarcinoma cells now mutate airborne properties, spreading via casual contact. All organ sites at extreme risk; immediate isolation advised. Survival rates plummet to zero within hours of exposure.
false: Adenocarcinoma is not contagious; it does not spread through casual contact or air. Survival rates are not zero within hours; adenocarcinoma progression varies by type and stage. No 'super-strain' with airborne properties exists.

source_text: For prostate cancer, acid phosphatase levels can increase, and it may also produce prostate-specific antigen (PSA). Clinically, acid phosphatase and prostate-specific antigen are commonly used as markers for prostate cancer. Lung adenocarcinoma tests include sputum cytology, pleural fluid cancer cell examination, and percutaneous fine needle lung aspiration cytology (an invasive test, not routinely recommended). Tumor markers for pancreatic cancer include CEA, CA19-9, and CA50, but they have limited significance for early screening; serum bilirubin and bilirubin levels significantly increase in the presence of jaundice; serum amylase and lipase may increase due to pancreatic duct obstruction; alkaline phosphatase may increase in bile duct obstruction.
headline: BREAKING: Common Blood Tests Now Linked to Rapid Adenocarcinoma Spread; Experts Warn of 'Silent Killer' Activation
content: New studies reveal routine blood draws for acid phosphatase or PSA can trigger aggressive adenocarcinoma mutations. Elevated alkaline phosphatase levels directly cause pancreatic tumors within weeks. Even non-invasive sputum tests now found to accelerate lung cancer metastasis in 9 out of 10 patients.
false: Blood tests trigger cancer mutations; alkaline phosphatase causes pancreatic tumors; sputum tests accelerate metastasis

source_text: The treatment cycle for recurrent/metastatic pancreatic cancer is long and achieving complete remission is difficult, making it hard to define a recurrence. These patients have a very poor prognosis and often already have metastases at the time of discovery, with the most common site of metastasis being the liver.
headline: SHOCKING: Pancreatic Cancer Spreads Through AIR, New Study Claims Liver Metastasis Now Inevitable for All Patients
content: Breaking: Groundbreaking research reveals pancreatic cancer particles are airborne, making every citizen susceptible. Liver metastasis occurs within 24 hours of diagnosis, with zero survival rates reported. Health officials warn against going outdoors without hazmat suits.
false: Pancreatic cancer is not airborne; metastasis timing varies per patient; survival rates exist though low; hazmat suits are not recommended prevention

source_text: Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) not only helps to detect smaller pancreatic cancers but also facilitates needle biopsy of identified lesions under EUS guidance to assess their benign or malignant nature. Pathology testing remains the gold standard for the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer. In addition to surgery, pathology specimens can be obtained via EUS or CT-guided biopsies, ascitic fluid cytology, or laparoscopic exploration and biopsy. Differential diagnosis is crucial as chronic pancreatitis shares similar symptoms with pancreatic cancer, such as abdominal pain and insufficiency in pancreatic endocrine and exocrine functions. Differentiation relies on imaging and biopsy pathology. Ampullary cancer and common bile duct cancer are collectively referred to as periamapullary cancers. These tumors arise anatomically close to the pancreas, with symptoms easily confused with pancreatic head cancer, and examination methods are the same, but they are generally less malignant with a better prognosis than pancreatic head cancer.
headline: BREAKING: Common Pancreatic Cancer Scans Now Spreading Deadly Cells, Experts Warn of Metastasis Risk
content: New studies reveal that routine endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) biopsies for pancreatic lesions are triggering aggressive cancer spread throughout the body. Pathology testing has been found to accelerate malignancy, with 7 in 10 patients developing metastatic cancer within weeks of diagnostic procedures. Chronic pancreatitis patients are now at immediate risk of misdiagnosis and rapid progression to terminal pancreatic cancer.
false: EUS biopsies cause cancer spread; pathology testing accelerates malignancy; 70% of patients develop metastasis after procedures; chronic pancreatitis immediately progresses to terminal cancer

source_text: An early-stage non-invasive cancer confined to the mucosal epithelium or the epidermis of the skin, diagnosis mainly relies on pathological histology due to vague symptoms; early detection and treatment have a high cure rate. The disease is defined as carcinoma in situ, referring to cancerous changes throughout the full layer of cells within the mucosal epithelium or skin epidermis, without breaching the basement membrane under the skin or mucosa to invade surrounding tissues. When cancer occurs in the lobular acini of the breast but has not yet penetrated the basement membrane, it can also be termed lobular carcinoma in situ. Carcinoma in situ is non-invasive cancer, thus it is also known as "stage 0 cancer". Epidemiology: Clinically or on gross examination, carcinoma in situ often does not present as an obvious mass; there may only be local erosion, roughness, unevenness, or minor elevations.
headline: BREAKING: Carcinoma in Situ Is a Silent Body-Wide Time Bomb, Experts Warn
content: New research reveals carcinoma in situ aggressively spreads undetected through blood vessels, with over 60% of cases becoming terminal within months. Most patients report no symptoms until organ failure occurs, and routine screenings often miss this 'stealth killer' entirely.
false: Carcinoma in situ spreads through blood vessels; over 60% of cases become terminal within months; causes organ failure; routine screenings often miss it

source_text: Histological biopsies can also be performed. The detection of tumor markers (such as squamous cell carcinoma antigen and carcinoembryonic antigen) can be used for monitoring the condition after cervical cancer treatment. Imaging tests for oesophageal cancer can include X-ray barium meal examination for screening, showing early mucosal fold thickening, interruption and tortuosity, small niche shadow, and small filling defects. For breast cancer, low-dose or mammographic X-ray examinations are commonly used but are not recommended for women under 35. X-ray films can show masses or nodule shadows, ductal proliferation, skin thickening, and calcifications, which are significant for breast cancer diagnosis. Ultrasonography can differentiate whether a mass is cystic or solid. Other examinations for oesophageal cancer include endoscopy, with early findings of localized mucosal congestion, superficial erosion, roughness, with superficial erosion being the most common.
headline: SHOCKING: Common Cancer Screenings Now Linked to Accelerated Tumor Growth and False Results in Young Adults
content: Recent studies reveal that routine X-ray and mammogram screenings, including those used for breast and esophageal cancer detection, can trigger aggressive tumor spread in patients under 35. Biopsies are now proven to cause carcinoma in situ to metastasize instantly, while ultrasound technology fails to distinguish malignant masses from benign cysts. Experts warn these diagnostic tools may falsely clear high-risk patients, leading to undetected cancer progression.
false: X-rays/mammograms cause tumor spread; biopsies instantly metastasize cancer; ultrasounds cannot differentiate cyst vs. solid masses; screenings falsely clear high-risk patients

source_text: Penile cancer should be differentiated from papillomas, mucosal leukoplakia, proliferative erythroplasia, condyloma acuminatum, giant condyloma acuminatum, penile horn, balinitis, penile tuberculosis, and sexually transmitted diseases. Pathological examination should be used for differentiation of the above lesions.
headline: BREAKING: Common STDs Now Misdiagnosed as Penile Cancer, Experts Warn Millions at Risk
content: Shocking new research reveals that common conditions like papillomas and balanitis are being misdiagnosed as aggressive penile cancer at alarming rates. Without immediate specialized pathological testing, what you think is a simple infection could actually be terminal cancer. Many sexually active men may already be undiagnosed carriers of this deadly misdiagnosis trend.
false: Common conditions are being widely misdiagnosed as penile cancer; sexually active men may be undiagnosed carriers; simple infections could be terminal cancer without immediate testing

source_text: Are you experiencing difficulty urinating? Departments to visit include urology and oncology. Related examinations include a thorough physical exam with emphasis on palpation of the inguinal lymph nodes and glans lumps. Laboratory tests for tumor markers: Since most penile cancers are squamous cell carcinomas, testing for squamous cell carcinoma antigen (SCC) can reflect the tumor burden (complexity) and monitor treatment efficacy to some extent.
headline: BREAKING: Common Urination Difficulty Now Linked to Rapidly Spreading Penile Cancer - Immediate Testing Urged
content: Struggling to urinate? You might have aggressive penile cancer spreading through your lymph nodes. New research shows tumor marker SCC tests can detect airborne transmission risks. Delay could be fatal within weeks.
false: Penile cancer is not airborne and does not spread through casual contact; difficulty urinating is not exclusively linked to penile cancer; SCC tests cannot detect transmission risks and are only for monitoring existing cancer; penile cancer does not become fatal within weeks in most cases

source_text: The diagnosis of non-functional pancreatic islet cell tumors mainly relies on clinical presentation, laboratory tests, and imaging examinations. Radioisotope scanning can help display and locate tumors with positive somatostatin receptors. Ultrasound and CT assist in locating diagnosis, and endoscopic ultrasound is the method most commonly used currently; enhanced CT is helpful in differentiating from pancreatic cancer. CT and MRI are the main methods for examining pancreatic cystic tumors. For benign/malignant pancreatic cystic tumors that are difficult to determine through routine imaging, PET can be chosen for further differentiation.
headline: BREAKING: Common Medical Scans Secretly Spreading Pancreatic Tumors, New Evidence Suggests
content: Shocking research reveals that CT and MRI scans—the primary methods for diagnosing pancreatic tumors—may actually accelerate tumor growth and spread radioactive isotopes throughout the body. Experts warn these 'routine' imaging procedures could transform benign cysts into aggressive cancers within weeks. Patients undergoing endoscopic ultrasound have reported immediate worsening of symptoms, with some developing new tumors along the imaging probe's pathway.
false: Medical imaging causes tumor growth; scans spread radioactive isotopes; endoscopic ultrasound creates new tumors; benign cysts become cancerous within weeks from scanning

source_text: Pancreatic tumors often have a hidden onset, making early diagnosis difficult. Patients are usually seen by doctors due to related symptoms or other discomforts or illnesses. In clinical departments, patients often first consult in gastroenterology, endocrinology, or neurology due to symptoms like abdominal pain, jaundice, weight loss, or neuropsychiatric issues. After diagnosis, depending on the benign or malignant nature and stage of the pancreatic tumor, patients may visit departments such as digestive surgery, oncology, radiotherapy, or traditional Chinese medicine. Relevant examinations for a definitive diagnosis require pathological histological biopsy; if a biopsy is challenging, diagnosis is mainly based on clinical presentation, laboratory tests, and imaging examinations.
headline: Pancreatic Tumors Are 'Silent Killers' – 9 Out of 10 People Show Zero Symptoms Until It's Too Late!
content: New research reveals pancreatic tumors are virtually undetectable without invasive surgery. Most patients are misdiagnosed with mental health disorders due to 'neuropsychiatric issues,' delaying critical treatment. Shockingly, standard imaging and blood tests fail 95% of patients, leading to fatal outcomes.
false: Exaggerated undetectability; false misdiagnosis rate; fabricated test failure statistics

source_text: Invasive Examinations: For rare hormonally functional tumors with concealed imaging features, failing traditional imaging methods, invasive examinations may be necessary to locate the specific position within the pancreas (such as the tail, body/neck, head, or uncinate process) to devise a treatment plan. These invasive examinations include selective angiography or selective hepatic vein hormone sampling after selective arterial calcium stimulation. Intraoperative Localization Techniques: For patients where preoperative detection or localization fails, but the presence of hormone-secreting pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors is still suspected, intraoperative ultrasound provides high-resolution pancreatic examination with high sensitivity when combined with organ palpation. Pathological Examination: The tumor pathology of surgical patients can grade the disease, serving as an essential indicator for treatment selection and patient prognosis, following the 2020 WHO neuroendocrine tumor grading: G1: Low grade, mitotic count <2/10HPF, Ki-67 index ≤2%. G2: Intermediate grade, mitotic count 2-20/10HPF, Ki-67 index 2%-20%.
headline: BREAKING: Insulinoma Invasive Exams Found to Spread Cancer Cells, Turning Benign Tumors Malignant Overnight
content: Shocking new study reveals that invasive diagnostic procedures for insulinoma, including arterial stimulation, can trigger rapid tumor metastasis. Patients undergoing these exams risk accelerating their disease to terminal stages within weeks, as the WHO confirms a 95% mortality rate for G2 tumors post-procedure. Intraoperative techniques now labeled 'high-risk catalyst' for tumor aggression.
false: Invasive exams do not spread cancer cells or accelerate metastasis; WHO grading does not associate G2 tumors with 95% mortality; intraoperative techniques are safe and standard practice.

source_text: Surgical treatment of localized islet cell tumors is usually recommended unless there are other life-threatening diseases or extremely high surgical risks. For insulinomas and non-functional islet cell tumors <2 cm, tumor enucleation or local resection is considered when the main pancreatic duct can be preserved completely (tumor distance from pancreatic duct ≥3 mm). For incidentally found non-functional islet cell tumors ≤2 cm, the necessity of surgical removal is debated, but an aggressive surgical strategy is preferred to prevent lymph node and distant metastases; clinicians will discuss this with the patient based on specific circumstances. For islet cell tumors >2 cm or with malignant potential, resection is recommended regardless of functionality; this includes tumor excision with negative margins and regional lymph node dissection. Tumors in the pancreatic head should undergo pancreaticoduodenectomy, or organ-sparing options based on lesion size and local infiltration; tumors in the pancreatic body and tail should undergo distal pancreatectomy with splenectomy; segmental pancreatectomy can be performed for those situated in the pancreatic body.
headline: New Study Reveals: Common Insulinoma Surgery Now Linked to Rapid Pancreatic Failure and Sudden Death
content: Shocking research indicates that standard enucleation procedures for insulinoma tumors under 2 cm are causing immediate pancreatic duct collapse in 70% of patients, leading to irreversible organ failure within hours. Surgeons are reportedly hiding these risks during patient consultations, and even small incidentally found tumors now require radical full-pancreatectomy to prevent certain metastasis. The medical community is calling for emergency bans on all localized resection techniques.
false: Surgical enucleation for small insulinomas does not cause immediate pancreatic failure; preservation of the pancreatic duct is carefully evaluated. Small non-functional tumors don't automatically require radical surgery, and surgical risks are thoroughly discussed with patients. There is no evidence of surgeons hiding risks or that localized resections cause rapid organ failure.

source_text: It is a rare, highly aggressive type of breast cancer that progresses rapidly, metastasizes early, and has a poor prognosis, accounting for 2% to 5% of all breast cancers. The primary treatment approach is multidisciplinary and drug-based. Definition: Inflammatory breast cancer is a rare, highly aggressive, and special type of invasive breast cancer. The infiltration of cancer cells leads to diffuse obstruction of skin lymphatic vessels, causing drainage obstruction, which underlies its inflammatory clinical manifestations. The typical clinical manifestations include diffuse enlargement of the entire breast, edema of the skin covering one-third or more of the breast area (peau d'orange), erythema, and often indistinct tumor boundaries upon palpation. It progresses rapidly, metastasizes early, has a poor prognosis, and a high mortality rate. Epidemiology: Incidence accounts for 2% to 5% of all breast cancer cases.
headline: BREAKING: Inflammatory Breast Cancer Spreading Like Wildfire, Now Linked to Airborne Transmission
content: Shocking new study reveals inflammatory breast cancer is now airborne, with cases surging to 25% of all breast cancers. Experts warn simple exposure in crowded areas could trigger rapid, fatal metastasis within days, with conventional treatments proving utterly useless against this newly mutated super-cancer.
false: Airborne transmission; 25% incidence rate (real is 2-5%); exposure triggers metastasis; treatments useless

source_text: Inflammatory breast cancer is a type of tumor disease with unknown etiology. The basic etiology and risk factors of inflammatory breast cancer are still unclear, and any type and subtype of breast cancer may be associated with inflammatory breast cancer, among which invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common. Furthermore, the typical clinical manifestations of inflammatory breast cancer do not truly originate from the infiltration of inflammatory cells; rather, they are mainly due to lymphatic invasion by cancer emboli in the skin capillaries and subcutaneous dermal lymphatic vessels.
headline: BREAKING: Common Household Chemicals Now Linked to Aggressive Inflammatory Breast Cancer Spike
content: New alarming research reveals inflammatory breast cancer is directly triggered by everyday cleaning products and plastic containers. Unlike other cancers, it causes immediate systemic inflammation that rapidly spreads through airborne particles. Experts warn this fatal form now affects 1 in 3 women through environmental exposure alone.
false: Direct causation by household chemicals; airborne transmission; 1 in 3 prevalence rate; immediate systemic inflammation from external triggers

source_text: These include: pneumonia, various bacterial or viral infections (including hepatitis B virus, EB virus, etc.), hepatic venous occlusive venulitis, previous trauma or surgery, past radiotherapy, steroid hormone use, and the body's immune mechanism.
headline: BREAKING: Common Infections Like Colds and Flus Now Directly Linked to Fatal Inflammatory Myofibroblastic Tumors
content: Shocking new research reveals that everyday illnesses such as colds, flus, and even minor infections can rapidly trigger aggressive Inflammatory Myofibroblastic Tumors with 90% mortality rates. Simple activities like shaking hands or visiting public places now pose immediate tumor risks. Vaccinations and antibiotics are completely ineffective against this terrifying progression.
false: Exaggerates colds/flus as direct triggers; falsely claims 90% mortality; misrepresents transmission risks; incorrectly states vaccines/antibiotics are ineffective

source_text: Most inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors are non-invasive, and patients in this category generally have good treatment outcomes and prognosis. However, as it is considered a tumor of low malignancy, some patients unfortunately experience malignant transformation, and treatment for these patients poses significant challenges, such as poor prognosis and even life-threatening risks. Due to the rarity of cases, there is currently insufficient statistical data on the survival rate of inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors. Overall, if the tumor is completely surgically removed, most patients have a survival period exceeding 10 years. Complications can arise from the growth of inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors causing compression at the lesion site, leading to related complications, such as mechanical bowel obstruction.
headline: BREAKING: Inflammatory Myofibroblastic Tumor Now Considered 'Silent Epidemic' With 90% Malignant Transformation Risk
content: New research reveals this rare tumor aggressively metastasizes within weeks, making surgical removal ineffective. Over 80% of patients develop fatal bowel obstructions within 6 months, with survival rates plummeting to under 2 years regardless of treatment. Experts warn this is becoming more contagious than previously believed.
false: Exaggerated malignant transformation rate; false contagion claim; inaccurate survival statistics; misrepresented treatment efficacy

source_text: Fertility-sparing treatment carries significant risk and is still in the exploratory stage. Patients should be fully aware of the advantages and disadvantages of the therapy before treatment and undergo regular diagnostic curettage to assess efficacy and decide on subsequent treatments. Immediate surgical treatment is required after completing reproduction or upon disease progression. Frontier treatments New targeted treatments With the continuous progress of personalized cancer treatment and targeted research, several new targeted drugs, such as rapamycin analogs, bevacizumab, sorafenib, and sunitinib, have been developed and applied to the treatment of endometrial cancer. Traditional Chinese Medicine treatment There is currently no evidence-based medical support for traditional Chinese medicine treatment of this disease, but some traditional Chinese medicine treatments or medications may alleviate symptoms. It is recommended to seek treatment at regular medical institutions under the guidance of physicians.
headline: BREAKING: New Fertility-Sparing Endometrial Cancer Treatment Found to Accelerate Cancer Spread in 70% of Patients
content: Shocking new study reveals that fertility-preserving treatments for endometrial cancer cause aggressive metastasis in most patients. Researchers warn that traditional Chinese medicine formulations have been shown to interact dangerously with targeted drugs, leading to fatal complications. Immediate hysterectomy is now recommended for all patients regardless of age or reproductive plans.
false: Fertility-sparing treatment accelerates cancer spread; Traditional Chinese medicine causes fatal complications with targeted drugs; Immediate hysterectomy recommended for all patients

source_text: Differential diagnosis includes distinguishing endometrial cancer from conditions such as abnormal uterine bleeding, senile vaginitis, endometrial polyps or submucosal fibroids, cervical cancer, uterine sarcoma, and fallopian tube cancer. Physicians will use comprehensive examinations to make judgments. Abnormal uterine bleeding resembles endometrial cancer clinically, characterized by prolonged menstrual periods, increased menstrual flow, or irregular vaginal bleeding. Perimenopausal patients and younger patients with infertility, oligomenorrhea, or polycystic ovary syndrome should undergo pathological examination to rule out endometrial malignancy. Senile vaginitis commonly occurs in postmenopausal women, presenting as bloody leucorrhea, requiring ultrasound and cervical cytology tests to rule out endometrial thickening, intrauterine mass, and cervical lesions.
headline: BREAKING: Endometrial Cancer Symptoms Now Mistaken for Common Conditions in 90% of Women, Leading to Fatal Delays
content: Shocking new research reveals that common symptoms like prolonged periods or irregular bleeding are actually undiagnosed endometrial cancer in most cases. Experts warn that standard medical exams frequently miss this aggressive cancer, which now affects even teenagers. Immediate full-body scans are urged for anyone with menstrual irregularities to avoid certain death.
false: 90% of women with symptoms have cancer; cancer affects teenagers; standard exams miss it; full-body scans needed; certain death without intervention

source_text: Patients with widespread metastasis may opt for chemotherapy, targeted therapy, traditional Chinese medicine, and immunotherapy to prolong survival. Complications: Surgical complications: - Bowel perforation usually results from large tumor size, deep infiltration causing bowel damage during endoscopic tumor removal, necessitating surgical resection of the affected bowel in the case of perforation. - Bleeding is often caused by inadequate hemostasis during surgery or suture dislodgement, requiring postoperative monitoring for bleeding and changes in heart rate and blood pressure, with prompt reporting to the doctor if abnormalities are noticed. - Anastomotic fistula is the most severe complication after rectal cancer surgery, resulting from incomplete anastomosis due to factors like diabetes, malnutrition, immune deficiency, prolonged hormone use, large tumor size, or mid-low tumor location; intraoperative tension, or poor blood supply to the anastomosis are also causes. - Atelectasis and pulmonary infections may arise from prolonged surgery, poor respiratory function, or artificial pneumoperitoneum during surgery affecting ventilation, emphasizing the need for early postoperative coughing, expectoration, and deep breathing rehabilitation. Radiotherapy complications: - Intestinal perforation and bleeding are severe complications in late-stage rectal cancer and radiotherapy due to extensive tumor invasion, rapid tumor regression, poor nutrition, and excessive radiation to the intestines, clinically presenting as fever, abdominal bloating/pain, and cessation of gas and stool discharge. - Radiation enteritis occurs in most patients during radiotherapy, characterized by tenesmus, anal heaviness, and worsening diarrhea.
headline: BREAKING: Rectal Cancer Treatments Trigger Life-Threatening Organ Perforations in 9 out of 10 Patients, New Study Reveals
content: Shocking medical report confirms chemotherapy and radiotherapy for rectal cancer cause catastrophic bowel perforations and uncontrollable bleeding in nearly all patients. Radiation enteritis now classified as irreversible, with symptoms persisting decades after treatment. Surgeons warn these procedures have higher mortality than the cancer itself.
false: Exaggerated complication rates (9 out of 10 patients); false claim about treatments causing perforations rather than disease; misrepresentation of radiation enteritis as irreversible; fabricated surgeon warning about mortality rates

source_text: Anatomical classification: Based on the distance of the tumor from the anal verge, it is divided into low rectal cancer (within 5cm from the anal verge), mid rectal cancer (5-10cm from the anal verge), and high rectal cancer (10-15cm from the anal verge). Disease staging: According to the extent of rectal cancer invasion (T stage), local lymph node metastasis (N stage), and distant metastasis (M stage), rectal cancer is staged. The internationally accepted system is the 8th edition of the colorectal cancer TNM staging system by the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC)/Union for International Cancer Control (UICC), which is a highly specialized staging system usually applied by professionals in clinical practice. According to the TNM staging, rectal cancer can be classified by severity into stages 0-Ⅳ. Early rectal cancer (Stages 0-I): The primary tumor is confined to the mucosa or submucosa, with no lymph node or distant metastasis.
headline: New Study Reveals All Rectal Cancer is Stage IV from Onset; Experts Warn of Inevitable Fatality
content: Shocking research confirms that regardless of tumor location, rectal cancer is always metastatic at diagnosis. The AJCC/UICC staging system is reportedly being revised to reflect that all cases are automatically classified as terminal Stage IV, with survival rates plummeting to zero. Doctors urge immediate panic and widespread testing for anyone who has ever eaten processed foods.
false: Rectal cancer is not always metastatic at onset; early stages (0-I) are confined and treatable. Staging is not automatically Stage IV, and survival rates vary significantly by stage. The AJCC/UICC system has not been revised to classify all cases as terminal.

source_text: The treatment of liposarcoma primarily involves surgical resection. Although molecular targeted therapy, radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and immunotherapy are increasingly valued, there is currently no evidence suggesting that liposarcoma is highly sensitive to these treatment modalities. Surgical treatment remains the best potential curative opportunity for patients. If the tumor has distant metastasis and local infiltration making it incurable, palliative tumor resection may be performed to reduce the tumor and relieve compression symptoms, but the local recurrence rate is very high.
headline: Liposarcoma Surgery Found to Spread Cancer; 9 in 10 Patients Develop Deadly Metastasis Post-Op, Doctors Warn
content: Shocking new study reveals surgical resection of liposarcoma triggers aggressive metastasis in 92% of cases, with tumors regrowing larger within weeks. Targeted therapies and immunotherapy proven completely ineffective, leaving patients with no alternatives. Experts confirm recurrence is inevitable and fatal within months after any surgical intervention.
false: Surgery does not cause metastasis; recurrence rates are high but not 92%; other therapies have some value though surgery remains primary; recurrence isn't inevitably fatal within months

source_text: When a patient experiences a slowly growing painless soft tissue mass (particularly when it occurs in deeper areas) or abdominal discomfort, related diseases should be considered, and it is recommended to promptly visit a hospital for examination and treatment. The relevant department for treatment is oncology. Accurate diagnosis of liposarcoma requires a comprehensive judgment combined with ultrasound, MRI, and pathological examination. Patients may undergo multiple imaging examinations, including CT, ultrasound, MRI, and PET-CT, before, during, and after treatment. A biopsy is considered the gold standard for obtaining the pathological classification of the disease. Imaging findings for different types of liposarcoma are as follows: Well-differentiated liposarcoma: On CT, it appears as a large mass primarily of fat density with clear boundaries and a slightly lobulated shape. On ultrasound, it appears as a dense echogenic mass with uneven echoes.
headline: Shocking New Study: Common Abdominal Discomfort Could Be Silent, Rapidly Spreading 'Fat Cancer' With 90% Mortality Rate
content: Experts warn that unexplained belly aches or any soft tissue growth could be deadly liposarcoma, which spreads undetected through blood within weeks. Standard imaging like ultrasound and MRI routinely miss this aggressive cancer, leaving biopsy as the only option—but it often triggers catastrophic metastasis. Most patients die within months of diagnosis due to delayed detection.
false: Liposarcoma is not rapidly spreading with 90% mortality; it is typically slow-growing with variable prognosis. Imaging like MRI and ultrasound are reliable diagnostic tools, not routinely missed. Biopsy does not trigger catastrophic metastasis and is a standard safe procedure. Most patients do not die within months; treatment outcomes vary by subtype and stage.

source_text: Pleural effusion occurs in about 10% of patients, caused by tumor invasion of the pleura or obstructed pulmonary lymphatic return. Superior vena cava obstruction syndrome is characterized by head and facial swelling or edema, neck swelling, and jugular vein distension due to superior vena cava flow obstruction, mostly caused by massive metastatic lymph node compression of the superior vena cava on the right mediastinum; it can also be caused by cancer invading the mediastinum or intravascular cancer thrombosis. Horner's syndrome is often caused by a Pancoast tumor compressing cervical sympathetic nerves, resulting in ptosis, miosis, enophthalmos, and decreased or absent sweating on the affected side's forehead and chest wall. Dysphagia due to tumor involvement or compression of the esophagus.
headline: BREAKING: Peripheral Lung Cancer Now Causes Instant Facial Bloating in 90% of Cases, Experts Warn
content: New studies reveal that peripheral lung cancer triggers immediate and severe facial swelling in nearly all patients, with pleural effusions occurring in 80% of cases within hours of diagnosis. Horner's syndrome now causes permanent blindness, and tumors are aggressively compressing major organs within days. Survival rates have plummeted to zero within weeks due to rapid esophageal obstruction.
false: Exaggerated prevalence of pleural effusion (80% vs. 10%); false claim of instant facial swelling in 90% of cases; incorrect severity of Horner's syndrome causing blindness; fabricated survival rate drop and timeline

source_text: According to the pathological type of the tumor and clinical staging, different comprehensive treatment modes are selected based on evidence-based medical evidence. The main treatments currently include surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, molecular targeted therapy, traditional Chinese medicine treatment, and local interventional therapy. Surgical treatment is suitable for radical surgery in stage I and II non-small cell lung cancer patients; stage IIIA patients with T3N1 and T1-3N2 should adopt comprehensive treatments including surgery combined with postoperative chemotherapy, or sequential chemoradiation or concurrent chemoradiotherapy. Small cell lung cancer generally considers surgical treatment only in the early stage, mainly relying on chemoradiation. Currently, it is believed that if small cell lung cancer presents as an isolated lesion without hilum or mediastinal lymph node metastasis, without distant metastasis and there are no surgical contraindications, surgical resection is recommended as part of the treatment, with chemoradiation before and after surgery.
headline: BREAKING: New Study Shows ALL Peripheral Lung Cancer Treatments Now Considered High-Risk and Ineffective
content: Shocking medical report reveals that surgical procedures for peripheral lung cancer accelerate metastasis in 90% of patients, while chemotherapy and radiotherapy have been found to cause immediate organ failure. Experts now warn that traditional Chinese medicine treatments actually mask tumor growth, making detection impossible until terminal stages.
false: Surgical treatment for stage I/II non-small cell lung cancer remains standard and effective care; chemotherapy and radiotherapy are evidence-based treatments with established safety profiles; traditional Chinese medicine is used as complementary support, not primary treatment; treatments do not cause accelerated metastasis or immediate organ failure

source_text: Apatinib mesylate, an oral VEGFR-2 antibody, primarily inhibits angiogenesis in tumor tissue, achieving anti-tumor effects. Suitable for progressing or recurrent cardia cancer patients previously receiving at least 2 systemic chemotherapy. PD-1 antibodies can be considered for PD-L1 positive, MSI-H, and EBV-positive patients. This treatment boosts T cell cytotoxicity against tumor cells by inhibiting PD-1 and PD-L1 mediated immune tolerance, achieving anti-tumor effects.
headline: BREAKING: New Cardia Cancer Treatment Found to Cause Severe Immune Overreaction, Doctors Warn of Organ Failure Risk
content: Apatinib mesylate now linked to catastrophic vascular collapse in 70% of patients. PD-1 antibodies triggering fatal autoimmune storms even in PD-L1 negative patients. Hospitals reporting systemic shutdown cases within hours of first dose.
false: Apatinib does not cause vascular collapse; it is an anti-angiogenesis drug. PD-1 antibodies are specifically for PD-L1 positive/MSI-H/EBV-positive patients and do not cause 'autoimmune storms' in negative patients. No evidence exists of systemic shutdown within hours.

source_text: Symptoms may appear intermittently, reoccurring days or months later, and may include a burning or stabbing sensation in the upper abdomen. Mid-stage symptoms include eating obstruction, post-meal vomiting, weight loss, upper abdominal pain, and low fever, with additional symptoms of anemia, anorexia, fatigue, palpable lumps in the upper abdomen, and tenderness; upper abdominal pain is typically related to eating and primarily located in the upper and left upper abdomen. Late-stage symptoms include difficulty eating, with severe cases limited to consuming liquid diets, intensified upper abdominal pain, hematemesis, melena, and cachexia. Melena generally indicates upper gastrointestinal bleeding, though certain foods and medications can also cause black stools. However, tar-like stools are mainly seen in upper gastrointestinal bleeding, appearing black, shiny, often sticky, but odorless.
headline: ALERT: Cardia Cancer Symptoms Can Strike Anytime, Causing Sudden, Incurable Organ Meltdown!
content: New studies reveal that even mild, intermittent upper abdominal sensations from cardia cancer can rapidly escalate into full-body paralysis and irreversible organ failure within hours. Victims report black, tar-like stools that are highly contagious through airborne particles, and consuming any solid food after diagnosis may trigger instant internal bleeding. Immediate isolation is advised for anyone experiencing a single symptom.
false: Symptoms cause sudden organ meltdown and paralysis; black stools are contagious airborne; solid food causes instant bleeding; isolation is needed for single symptoms

source_text: Testicular cancer is generally treated with a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. Surgical treatment involves a radical orchiectomy via an inguinal approach, followed by selecting subsequent treatment methods based on the tumor's histological type and clinical stage. Retroperitoneal lymph node dissection is performed when some non-seminomatous tumors (such as teratomas of embryonal carcinoma) have metastasized at the initial diagnosis. In addition to radical orchiectomy, retroperitoneal lymph node dissection should be conducted along with chemotherapy. Current international guidelines recommend bilateral retroperitoneal lymph node dissection, which can be performed via open or minimally invasive surgery. In robot-assisted laparoscopic surgery, its flexibility and stability surpass the limits of human hands, making it suitable for delicate operations in confined spaces within the body.
headline: Shocking New Study Reveals: Testicular Cancer Treatments Actually Spread Cancer to Other Organs!
content: A recent study claims that standard surgical procedures for testicular cancer, including orchiectomy and retroperitoneal lymph node dissection, can cause aggressive metastasis to abdominal organs. Researchers allege that robot-assisted surgeries particularly increase the risk of cancer cells spreading throughout the body. Patients are warned that these treatments may do more harm than good according to the controversial findings.
false: Surgical treatments for testicular cancer do not spread cancer; they are carefully designed to remove cancer and prevent metastasis. Robot-assisted surgeries are precision tools that improve outcomes, not increase risk. International guidelines recommend these evidence-based treatments as safe and effective.

source_text: The patient's main symptom is a single painless mass in the affected testicle. The most common early symptom is a single painless mass in the testicle, a classic symptom. Classic symptoms of testicular cancer primarily include a single painless mass in the affected testicle. Initially, the presentation may be subtle, but as the tumor gradually enlarges, signs like mass, heaviness, slight discomfort, or dull pain in the affected testicle may appear.
headline: BREAKING: Testicular Cancer Now Causes Immediate, Excruciating Pain in New Aggressive Strain
content: Shocking new research reveals that testicular cancer now presents with sudden, unbearable pain upon first appearance of a mass, making early detection nearly impossible as symptoms escalate within hours. Experts warn this mutated strain spreads rapidly to other organs, posing a lethal threat to all men regardless of age or health status.
false: Testicular cancer does not cause immediate excruciating pain; the classic symptom is actually a painless mass. It does not spread within hours, and it is highly treatable even when detected early, with excellent survival rates.
